comments:
Principles of Physics II focuses on Electromagnetism and Radiation. Major topics include: Electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena. This course fulfills the Physical World Sector requirement.

A few students described the course as time-consuming, “difficult,” and “challenging.” This was especially true with respect to the derivation of formulas, which many students said served as a big portion of the class. However, a few students said the material was interesting although sometimes it could be “too abstract to delve into.” Some students also mentioned that a lot of emphasis is placed on quizzes.

For the most part, students were very happy with Professor Williams. Students stated that he always made himself available if necessary, and he made sure that students who were confused with the material understood it so that they could “thrive” in the class. One student said that Professor Williams is “very patient in going through examples and answering questions about concepts.” Another student said that if it weren’t for Professor Williams, he/she “probably would have lost all of [his/her] interest in physics.” While most students felt that Professor Williams was “wonderful,” and “fantastic,” some students were not as pleased with Professor Williams’ teaching style. A few students stated that he was “boring” his explanations were not as helpful as the textbook as he would rush through problems. Finally, one student thought that the midterms were “stringent” due to other professors’ contributions.

Many students felt that this course was intended for majors. One student commented that as an electrical engineering major, “I found much of the content of this course relevant to my field. However, the knowledge gained from this course may never serve any practical purpose for students in most other majors.” Another student states that any College student “is at a disadvantage” because of the breadth of math and science information that Engineering students have been exposed in addition to “the fact that this is review for most people.”

Principles of Physics II focuses on Electromagnetism and Radiation. Major topics include: Electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena. This course fulfills the Physical World Sector requirement.

A few students described the course as time-consuming, “difficult,” and “challenging.” This was especially true with respect to the derivation of formulas, which many students said served as a big portion of the class. However, a few students said the material was interesting although sometimes it could be “too abstract to delve into.” Some students also mentioned that a lot of emphasis is placed on quizzes.

Students overwhelmingly praised Professor Sako, stating that he was either the best professor they have ever had at Penn or simply “excellent” and “amazing.” Many students thought Professor Sako was very approachable before and after the lecture and even outside of the classroom. Students also thought that Professor Sako was well organized and that he enthusiastically and clearly explained the material. One student thanked Professor Sako for getting rid of “unnecessary guesswork,” which helped students “grasp the material.” Professor Sako received minor criticism. One student said that because Professor Sako was so thorough, he would often get behind the other professors but that the quality of teaching style made the flaw seem minimal. Other students stated that not enough homework problems were discussed in class.

Many students felt that this course was intended for majors. One student commented that as an electrical engineering major, “I found much of the content of this course relevant to my field. However, the knowledge gained from this course may never serve any practical purpose for students in most other majors.” Another student states that any College student “is at a disadvantage” because of the breadth of math and science information that Engineering students have been exposed in addition to “the fact that this is review for most people.”

Principles of Physics II focuses on Electromagnetism and Radiation. Major topics include: Electric and magnetic fields; Coulomb's, Ampere's, and Faraday's laws; Maxwell's equations; emission, propagation, and absorption of electromagnetic radiation; interference, reflection, refraction, scattering, and diffraction phenomena. This course fulfills the Physical World Sector requirement.

A few students described the course as time-consuming, “difficult,” and “challenging.” This was especially true with respect to the derivation of formulas, which many students said served as a big portion of the class. However, a few students said the material was interesting although sometimes it could be “too abstract to delve into.” Some students also mentioned that a lot of emphasis is placed on quizzes.

Most students were not too pleased with Professor Martino. One student said that there was too much emphasis on textbook problems and that “a lecture on the material and overview of the chapter would be helpful.” Another student said that Professor Martino was disorganized and that his knowledge of the material was “well below sufficient.” This student also said that his “hand-writing and diagrams on the blackboard were so unclear.” Another student stated that Professor Martino would make many mistakes on the board, both of which made the class even more confusing. While a majority of students criticized Professor Martino’s teaching style, one student did comment that this was Professor Martino’s first semester teaching and that he did show improvement throughout the semester.

Many students felt that this course was intended for majors. One student commented that as an electrical engineering major, “I found much of the content of this course relevant to my field. However, the knowledge gained from this course may never serve any practical purpose for students in most other majors.” Another student states that any College student “is at a disadvantage” because of the breadth of math and science information that Engineering students have been exposed in addition to “the fact that this is review for most people.”

This course is based on the seven student comments submitted.
